text: I wouldn't describe it as a place at the
negotiating table I would describe it as
a car being part of a conversation in
which it becomes very clear to Iran and
to Russia what the coalition countries
are expecting in terms of a settlement
in Syria it could be based on the Geneva
1 formula a that the setting up of a
transitional governing council that
would have full executive powers to
ensure that they can maintain state
institutions for civil and military the
departure of Bashar al-assad the writing
of a constitution and the holding of
Elections
but the Americans and the British have
accepted that President Bashar al-assad
can stay in Park for a short time during
the transition would you agree to that
our position I believe the position of
the countries in the coalition is really
a unanimous one we may have slightly
different ways of expressing it but
we're basically saying the same thing
what we are saying is that at the
beginning of the process it has to be
very very clear to the Syrian people
that Bashar al-assad will leave by a
date certain
it can't be probable it can't be
possible it has to be certain and then
that date will depend on how quickly one
can transition power to the to the
governing council and how quickly one
can take over the security forces in
Syria to ensure that the security forces
don't collapse and the civil
institutions don't collapse this is the
most serious sustained diplomatic
questios in the conflict how do you rate
its chances of success you hope for the
best and prepare for the worst I'm not a
gambler so I can't put odds on success
or failure but what I what I have seen
is that over the past few months there
has been a coming together or of the
forming of a consensus among the allied
countries and where we are now trying to
see if gaps can be bridged between the
allied countries were supporting the
moderate Syrian opposition and the
Russian position but at the same time as
you're stepping up the talks you're
stepping up the military supplies with
this talk of even ground troops of
ground raids that that's what the United
States is saying without a doubt
we have to support the Syrian opposition
as if there are no peace talks we have
to intensify that support we have to
contribute to changing the balance of
power on the ground because that
ultimately will open up the the door for
the departure of Bashar al-assad and
what President Bashar al-assad refuses
to go after all he does have support
within the country he will go there is
no doubt about it he will go
he will go either through a political
process or he will be removed by course
there is no doubt that he will go I want
to ask you about Yemen because as you
know Saudi Arabia is being accused of
war crimes in Yemen there was an attack
this week on a hospital of medicine
phone chair there's been 39 attacks on
health facilities I know there are
attacks by the other side by the Houthis
but Saudi Arabian you're in the
coalition is being accused of
indiscriminate attacks we believe
unjustly with regards to the hospital by
Doctors Without Borders they contacted
the coalition of vivo week or 10 days
ago and gave us the coordinates for the
location of their facility so why would
we take the coordinates and vomit
doesn't make sense and when we looked at
the you're saying someone else bombed it
we believe it was the result of
surface-to-surface missiles we don't we
don't believe it was any allied
operations we had some operations
perhaps 10 kilometers away from that
facility and so we believe it could have
been Houthi attacks we have seen this
before when the coalition forces in
conduct operations against military
targets and they hit those targets we
noticed that the Houthis attack
buildings nearby and claim that this is
either collateral damage or that this
attack was permitted by the coalition
forces we have absolutely no issue with
anyone investigating these attacks in
order to establish the facts
